Posts.Content: I am 4 months post surgery, and have had pains in my penis from the get-go. I just figured it was part of the recovery. When I pee it hurts in the head just as the stream stops. But the discomfort has increased to having a slight pain while walking around. I am going in to be checked for an Urinary Tract Infection, but I have no burning sensation. I am concerned about scare tissue etc. I have a call into my Urologist but haven't gotten a response as of yet. Any help. Tonight I have had a few beers and the pain is gone, and the stream is longer and stronger. Sometimes I get the urge to pee when I really don't have much to go, but when I go the stream is short and that is when it hurts. If it is a long stream I don't have any pain. Any thoughts? Lance Maybe I just need to stay drunk. LOL

Posts.Title: Blood tests done. Di.vinci at 10am tues

Posts.Content: Thanks guy's. I went to my GP and he was convinced it was UTI, even said there was blood in my urine. But when the urine analysis came back it showed no infection. I have an appointment with my Urologist next Mon. My GP gave me some Pyridium to take and it gets rid of the pain and also turns your urine bright orange. The pain I have is an irritating pain right when my Sphincter closes. And at times I get a feeling like something is poking me inside like a slight pricking sensation. I'm wondering if it is a stitch that was supposed to dissolve, and didn't. Seems I read on here once of someone having that problem. Also am a little tender right down between my legs. Like when I sit in the saddle and get bumped up there it hurts a little. I forgot to add that the pain in the sphincter seems to happen more when I stand to pee. When sitting it seldom hurts. Will let you all know what the Urologist says. Lance

Posts.Title: Suggestions? Experience?

Posts.Content: Yes Newporter, I believe Chuck is right about the 4+4, if in the core sample just managed to get 4's, then there is no secondary #, so it is assigned another 4 even though if the core sample was a little larger or to the right or left so to speak, they would have found some more 3's. Not a pathologist but it makes sense to me. It did jump up to a stage T3a because it had left the capsule. I have finished reading Dr. Walsh's book today. WOW! what an education. I like his statement on page 376. "If there is capsular penetration with negative margins, the surgery did the best job any form of treatment could do". This is in defense of surgery being the gold standard. Lance .

Posts.Title: My First Post after reading for 18 months

Posts.Content: Well, everything went as well as expected, aside from stomach pains that kept me for a second night. Dr. said the lymph nodes looked good. Will have the path report back on Mon. Some discomfort in my stomach which is expected I guess. Hope for good results from the path but am aware that the Gleason score will probably go up & there is a good possibility that it will be found in the lymph nodes & seminal vesicles. However at this time I am happy to have it out and we will deal with whatever happens. Lance

Posts.Title: 2 Days after RRP with Di Vinci

Posts.Content: Good news! The cancer had left the capsule, however the surgical margins were neg. Lymph nodes were neg. Gleason score did not change. So according to the chart in Dr. Walsh's book, I have a 41% of still having an undetectable PSA after 10 years. After actually reading the report, it looks like it was caught just in time, It was heading towards the lymph nodes because I had Lympovascular invasion. Thanks for all the support & encouragement everyone. Lance

Posts.Title: 2 Days after RRP with Di Vinci

Posts.Content: Well, everything went as well as expected, aside from stomach pains that kept me for a second night. Dr. said the lymph nodes looked good. Will have the path report back on Mon. Some discomfort in my stomach which is expected I guess. Hope for good results from the path but am aware that the Gleason score will probably go up & there is a good possibility that it will be found in the lymph nodes & seminal vesicles. However at this time I am happy to have it out and we will deal with whatever happens. Lance

Posts.Title: 2 Days after RRP with Di Vinci

Posts.Content: Yes Newporter, I believe Chuck is right about the 4+4, if in the core sample just managed to get 4's, then there is no secondary #, so it is assigned another 4 even though if the core sample was a little larger or to the right or left so to speak, they would have found some more 3's. Not a pathologist but it makes sense to me. It did jump up to a stage T3a because it had left the capsule. I have finished reading Dr. Walsh's book today. WOW! what an education. I like his statement on page 376. "If there is capsular penetration with negative margins, the surgery did the best job any form of treatment could do". This is in defense of surgery being the gold standard. Lance .

Posts.Title: Joined the Club

Posts.Content: Hi poppygirl, Sorry to hear of all your problems, but that's what we are here for. First off, don't get too worried at this point. Doing a biopsy is just standard procedure if your PSA is elevated and the prostate is enlarged. The fact that the CT scan was neg. is a positive sign. Having a hard spot on the gland is what caught my Drs. attention, within 6 weeks I was in surgery, and I am looking forward to a long life. Take each day as it comes, get the biopsy and wait, (the hardest part) for the results and deal with them from there. If the results are positive, don't panic! It is scary stuff I have to admit, but you will get through it. His PSA numbers were not excessively high so that is a good sign. What you want to get from the Dr. when you get the results is what is called a Gleason score, and for example if it is a 7, it makes a difference if it is 3+4 or 4+3, and the stage. With that you will be able to get a lot of info. as to your best options. Also if it is positive I would highly recommend getting Dr. Walsh's book, Surviving Prostate Cancer, it is easy reading and will provide you with just about all you will ever need to know. Good Luck, Lance

Posts.Title: so worried for my partner :(

Posts.Content: Fran, I am 10 weeks out and I was experiencing the samething as you.At 3 weeks I was dry, then the next da I started leaking a little. Did get a urinary infection, probably from being in such close contact with a wet pad. Like you as soon as I would stand I would loose it.I would drink a tea start raining almost immediately. Just constant little squirts, but when I went to the bathroom I couldn't go because it was all out. It gradually got better. Seems to go in weekly spurts. This week I am wearing the Depends Shield's and they are staying dry. Like you I never had a problem at night or when sitting, except when I had the infection, then I was leaking at night. So like the rest said keep up with the Kegels, I had pretty much stopped at 3 weeks, didn't know this was a lifetime affair. I thought once the muscle was strengthened that I was good. Now I try to do 10 every hour or so, or when going to the bathroom. My doctor considers leaking a drop or so when lifting as continent.

Posts.Title: Strong Stream/ Low Volume

Posts.Content: Hi Guy's I read in Dr. Walsh's book that because of having an enlarged Prostate that our bladders get thicker. I am 4 weeks post op, when I am sitting sometimes I have to pee so bad my bladder aches, when I go I have a strong stream but it doesn't last near as long as you would think. Does anyone know if this is do to the bladder not stretching like it used to due to the thickening? My wife is an Ultra sound Tech. She says bladders can usually stretch a lot. Also sometimes I feel I have to go and I start getting some dripping but when I go the stream is strong for about 3 seconds and stops. Nothing serious, just wondering, Lance

Posts.Title: Pathology Report and Sex

Posts.Content: <.01 Great news WiseOldFool! Hang in there it does get better. Or at least it has with me. Leakage gets better with time, and don't be surprised if it bounces between good & bad for a while. I am 6 mos. post op. I have never needed a pad at night. But now I am down to wearing a thin Depends Shield in the day. I get a few leaks during the day, sometimes for no apparent reason, but mostly when simply blowing my nose or something dumb like that. In my case they did not spar the nerves, and according to my surgeon he was glad that he didn't attempt to. That being said, ED is a given. But if they sparred your nerves, don't give up hope. You have a good attitude about the whole deal, you'll do fine. I feel it was a bump in the road, and if no more intercourse is what I m dealt, well, so be it. I am still alive and having fun with whatever time Good Lord gives me. Sex was great! but there is a lot more to life than sex. And, there are still other sexual options besides intercourse. Wecome to the zero club, Good luck, & merry Christmas, Lance Good

Posts.Title: Omega 3 and PC

Posts.Content: Haliday, Sorry you had to join our club, I agree with Otago, I wouldn't wait until next year. They normally make you wait 6-8 weeks after the biopsy before the surgery, so that everything has had a chance to heal. As for the side affects, most of us will tell you they aren't that bad. The main thing is to get the cancer out, the second is continence, (that will affect you more that sex), the third is sex, even if you did just get married. If they are unable to spar the nerves there are still plenty of options to have a gratifying sex life. Trust me I know because they were unable to save my nerves. Had they tried there was a good chance they would have left some cancer behind. Better limp that dead! But the orgasms are fantastic! Like my wife reminded me, half the population has orgasms without an erection. WOMEN! Good luck with your journey, Lance

Posts.Title: Incontinence is back!

Posts.Content: I am 8 weeks out today. Thee weeks after the catheter was removed I was dry. Then I went back to just wearing a light Depends Shield during the day. Last weekend went camping and rode our recumbent bikes 35 miles on Fri. & 29 miles on Sat. the 7 on Sun. I have never gotten sore from riding but this past weekend my groin area was tender and progressed to get down right sore. Then I noticed that I was leaking a lot & the urine burned slightly when dripping. Called the Urologist and she put me on Cipro. thinking that I have a urinary infection. The pain is subsiding after 2 days, still not sure if I damaged a muscle or something else. But I am leaking big time again. I had backed off on the Kegels thinking that I didn't want to over do them, but now am doing them a lot to try and get things under control again. As long as I am sitting or lying down I am fine, but as soon as I stand I can feel myself leaking. Also when I urinate, the stream comes out strong then when it stops it is abrupt and I get a slight pain inside the meatus. Any input would be welcome. I drink only decaf tea, so I don't think that should be the problem. But the leaking almost seems to be getting worse. Not sure what is normal at this point. Lance

Posts.Title: Incontinence is back!

Posts.Content: Thanks MoHawk! I needed that. My pain was more in the pubic area, and into my groin a little. I have stayed off my bike since Sun. and am not in any pain any more but still leaking more than before. The pain was pretty intense, if I was sitting and got up to walk it was all I could do to move my legs. Felt like real sore muscles. Posts.Title: Dont even know where to start

Posts.Content: Hi Alex, Welcome to our little club, I know this was not your intent. Like you, I was recently diagnosed with PCa about 1 - 1 /2 weeks ago. I am not going to try and sway you in your decision as to your plan of attack. Personally, I could never take the wait & see attitude. I can't imagine living my life with it hanging over my shoulder. In my research, I have found that the rate of success is equal between RRP & EBR. However, my uncle who is 2 yrs. older that me, was talked out of RRP by his Oncologist. The cancer came back last year after 5 years. He wanted to have it removed & was told by the Dr.s at University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, that they don't do that anymore as the results, and I quote " would be Morbid & Daunting". When I was diagnosed, I made the decision there & then to have it removed. I am 66,healthy, and plan on living to be a ripe old age. My surgery is scheduled for next Tue. with the "Di Vinci". I went with my intuition and didn't want to talk with anyone & have them change my mind. But, can't say that I'm not damned scared! Not about the surgery, but the outcome. That being said, this is a great forum, there are a lot of great guy's on it with great advice & knowledge, read a lot and learn all you can. I know I have! Myself, I have made my decision and won't have anyone else to blame if things don't work out as planned, and I won't look back. Remember we are all here for each other. Good luck in your journey, Lance

Posts.Title: Second PSA

Posts.Content: Krugzz, I am 6 weeks out. The first 2 days after the cath. was out I would over fill a Max Pad if I wasn't paying attention. By 3 weeks I was mostly dry. Never have a problem when sitting or lying down. When I stand up I usually need to head to the bathroom. I had my nerves removed, I don't know if that makes a difference or not. The Dr. said I would end up with a drip now & then when lifting something heavy. I wear a light shield daily for assurance. I can usually manage the day on one. Get some dribbles now & then but I am happy with the results so far. I wouldn't worry about it to much. You'll do fine. My biggest fear was being one of those people you stand behind at the checkout counter and they reek of urine.

Posts.Title: continence?

Posts.Content: No not really, he suggested I keep the bike riding to 5 miles. I keep it geared low so there is no strain, and the bike trail is flat & paved. Taking the fence down was mostly walking so I figured that was good. I was told to not lift over 20#, which I have pretty well stuck to. I feel great and I hate just sitting around. You know what they say, you can't keep a good man down Now that you mention it, I recall him saying no raking or any thing like that. I guess I'll try to do less. Lance

Posts.Title: Nomograms - Kinda cool

Posts.Content: Dr. Walsh's book has a section on reoccurrence that he says is 95% accurate. But he points out that, these numbers were from men in the 80's when most men were diagnosed later age and their tumors were more advanced. But it gives you and idea. My Dr. said I probably have a 50/50 chance of my PSA rising within 10 yrs. The chart in the book gave me a 60% chance. Whatever, you should just live life to the fullest and don't worry about it. I had my surgery 10 days ago, and yesterday and today both, I road my recumbent bike/trike 14 miles each day. Went out & took down a bunch of fences today. I couldn't feel better. Lance

Posts.Title: 1st PSA Post op

Posts.Content: John, My heart goes out to you, yours is one of the worst experiences I have read about on this forum. But believe me, we are all here rooting for you. Don't give up the fight. Posts.Title: 5 Days Post Surgery

Posts.Content: ddayglo, I had the same question a while back. It was pointed out to me that if the surgeon missed getting all of it, there by leaving a positive margin that some how he was a bad surgeon. But my surgeon said that when doing the surgery they can't tell good tissue from bad. I get the impression that it is good guess work and luck. If the margin comes back positive, it means that they found cancer cells at the surgical margins, and that it is very possible that more cancer cells are beyond the surgical cuts. Just my impression, Lance

Posts.Title: Surgery Monday

Posts.Content: Jacjakay, as for the smell problem. I always kept a zip lock bag next to the toilet to put them in. It helped a lot. I agree with the others. I gave up beer & coffee for 3 months after surgery. I am now 6 months out and wear a thin Depends shield but just more for security than anything else. It is usually dry at the end of the day. Also, if he doesn't do the kegels, he won't progress much. He has to want to try to do better. The male external catheters do work! There is one out their that medicare will even supplement the cost, but I don't recall the name. I had one, but the Dr. didn't want me using it because he felt I would learn to depend on it and get lazy with the Kegels. Lance

Posts.Title: Dre ?

Posts.Content: In my situation, the prostate was never extremely large, but enlarged. PSA creped up slowly over the years to 4.1. For the last year or so I was on Jalyn which dropped my PSA down to 1.1 & shrunk the Prostate. My Dr. thinks that because of the shrinkage is why the hard spot was felt & I got a biopsy. So for me, I look at it as almost an accident that it was found. So like Chuck said I would keep on top of it. Lance Wish me luck, heading down for my bone scan.
Posts.Title: Newbie here

Posts.Content: Powderfinger, I'm sorry to hear of your plight, it has been rough, I can see. You fail to mention what your Gleason score is. That makes a big difference. Myself, I could not imagine taking the chance that it would come back. I chose surgery right from the start, and knowing the possible side affects was just part of the deal. After 4 months the incontinence is down to the point I don't worry about it. Since they could not spar my nerves the ED is a fact of life. However, even at 66 my wife and I had a good sex life and continue to. We need to do things a little differently, but the orgasms are better that ever and come April I may or may not have a penile implant. I have read great things about them. But my biggest concern is at 67 by then, do I want to endure the pain of another surgery. Haven't decided yet. My wife is happy with the way things are, so it is my choice. As for the surgery itself, it's a piece of cake. Very little pain and discomfort, just have to take it easy for about 6weeks. My problem with Radiation is that my uncle who is 2 years older than me wanted surgery and was talked out of it by the radiologist in 2007. So he had radiation. Last year in 2012 it came back and he wanted them to take it out. He was told that because of the scaring from the radiation that very few surgeons would attempt it. So he had to settle with Cryo., which shows hope but is not proven to work yet. So this is my only concern with radiation. If it fails it leaves you with few options. If you have it removed it is gone and unless it is very advanced, you have a very good chance of being done with it. Basically, the way I look at it is all the other choices are a crap shoot as to if it worked, because you just have to sit back and wait and see what happens. Remove it and you know it is gone. This is just my opinion and I know others have theirs. You will do what feels right for you. I would definitely suggest you get a copy of Dr. Welch's book " Surviving Prostate Cancer" and reading it. It is easy reading, but will tell you everything you need to know to make a good decision. Good luck! Lance

Posts.Title: New member, just diagnosed.

Posts.Content: Powderfinger, I'm sorry to hear of your plight, it has been rough, I can see. You fail to mention what your Gleason score is. That makes a big difference. Myself, I could not imagine taking the chance that it would come back. I chose surgery right from the start, and knowing the possible side affects was just part of the deal. After 4 months the incontinence is down to the point I don't worry about it. Since they could not spar my nerves the ED is a fact of life. However, even at 66 my wife and I had a good sex life and continue to. We need to do things a little differently, but the orgasms are better that ever and come April I may or may not have a penile implant. I have read great things about them. But my biggest concern is at 67 by then, do I want to endure the pain of another surgery. Haven't decided yet. My wife is happy with the way things are, so it is my choice. As for the surgery itself, it's a piece of cake. Very little pain and discomfort, just have to take it easy for about 6weeks. My problem with Radiation is that my uncle who is 2 years older than me wanted surgery and was talked out of it by the radiologist in 2007. So he had radiation. Last year in 2012 it came back and he wanted them to take it out. He was told that because of the scaring from the radiation that very few surgeons would attempt it. So he had to settle with Cryo., which shows hope but is not proven to work yet. So this is my only concern with radiation. If it fails it leaves you with few options. If you have it removed it is gone and unless it is very advanced, you have a very good chance of being done with it. Basically, the way I look at it is all the other choices are a crap shoot as to if it worked, because you just have to sit back and wait and see what happens. Remove it and you know it is gone. This is just my opinion and I know others have theirs. You will do what feels right for you. I would definitely suggest you get a copy of Dr. Welch's book " Surviving Prostate Cancer" and reading it. It is easy reading, but will tell you everything you need to know to make a good decision. Good luck! Lance

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by lancepeace Surgery or radiation are both valid options. The surgery may help you urinate when you are old. Radiation might have milder urinary and sexual side effects. What is your PSA history and prostate size? Good luck. Thanks for the response. PSA is 1.7 & Prostate is small. I have been on Jalyn for the past year which shrunk the Prostate. Dr. thinks that now that the gland is smaller was why he was able to feel the hard spot. PSA was never really high. crept up to 4 over the years, but went down when I went on Advardt. I have done a lot of reading over the past couple days. I understand all the side effects & radiations a lot easier, but after seeing what happened with my uncle I don't want to get locked into not having any options down the road. My Dad had his removed at 70 because he didn't want the 15 yrs. they gave him hanging over his head.

Posts.Title: By The Numbers

Posts.Content: I just found out Fri. that I have Prostate Cancer. Had 3-7's & 1-8 on the Gleason scale. Go in for my CT scan tomorrow, see the Dr. Tue. & get bone scan on Thur. My Dr. specializes in Robotic Surgery, & Radioactive Seeds. I am a healthy 66 yr. old. very active, (biked 3000 miles last yr.) Kayak, & horse trail ride. From the get go I am thinking surgery. Get it out & get on with having fun. If it should come back I always have the Radiation option. My Dad had his removed, & 1 of his bros. died from it & 1 who is 2 yrs. older that I got it in 2007. He was talked out of surgery by his oncologist. But when it came back a year ago he was told that because he had had radiation that they do not remove them anymore because the results were Morbid & Daunting. Any thoughts on my choice?

Posts.Title: My pathology report

Posts.Content: I had my biopsy a week ago. Came back positive 3- 7's & 1-8. Go in for my CT scan tomorrow, bone scan Thur. Will see the Dr. this Tue. to discuss options. I am a healthy 66. Biked 3000 miles last yr. Kayak & horse trail ride. My Dr. specializes in Robotic surgery, & radio active seeds. From the get go I am thinking surgery. Get it out & don't have to worry about it, & if it does come back I always have Radiation to fall back on. Any thoughts on my choice? My uncle who is 2 yrs. older than I was talked into Radiation by his Oncologist in 2007, it came back a year ago & was told they don't remove them after Radiation anymore because the results are Morbid & Daunting. He had to have cryosurgery.

Posts.Title: Diagnosed 2 days ago.

Posts.Content: Hay, that was great to hear. Thanks for the encouragement. This whole thing sort of took the wind out of my sail this past weekend. I am very active & plan on making it to 100 God willing. Over the last few years I have gone from 242lbs. down to a healthy 160, from a 42" waist to a 32" and I feel better than I have in years. Thanks Sarg. I will know more this afternoon or tomorrow. My wife works with the Radiologist, so she might be able to get him to read my scan before going home today.

Posts.Content: Without more info. it is hard to advise. When was surgery? You need to post your stats. From your post the best advice I can give you is on the Kegal's. To do them properly, you want to squeeze the muscles that you would if you were trying to hold back a fart. Also, the same muscle you use to try and get the last drop of urine out. When doing them right your dick will rise a little. Lance

Posts.Title: 6 weeks post ralp

Posts.Content: WJW, hang in there, it will get better. At 3 weeks I was dry, but by 6 weeks I was leaking like a sieve. It has been up & down. Now after week 10 I am dry all day with just a drip when I try to lift something heavy, and even then I can stop it. So at 6 weeks, just keep up the kegel's and hopefully you will start seeing rapid improvement. Seems to improve weekly as opposed to daily, just an observation. Lance

Posts.Title: Pathology results

Posts.Content: Hi Bob, I am 6 months out and couldn't fel better. kayaked for 3 hrs. today and road 60 miles on my recumbent this past week. 40 one day 20 the other. That being said, after my surgery my instructions were to do nothing more than walking for 6 weeks, I was back on my bike after about 3, riding about 15 miles. Looking back I think it was not helping me with the incontinence, may have set me back a little. I don't remember being tired though. In fact I was amazed at how good I felt. But that is just me I tend to over do it after surgery's. For what it is worth, just hang in there. Things will get better, it just takes time. Some of us think we are in great shape because we work out regularly. Going to a gym vs. regular physical work and exercise do not compare. Sorry, don't get me wrong. I am not saying that working out at the gym. is not good. But lets face it sitting at a desk all day and going to the gym a couple hr.s a week does not compare to someone who is physically active from morning to night and does hard physical exercise on top of it.

Posts.Title: Post Op recovery, what is the real time

Posts.Content: Omegaman, sorry you had to join our little club. In my opinion you are making the right choice in having it removed. At 50 you have a lot of years ahead of you and if radiation were to fail, ( you won't know until it comes back), most Drs. won't remove it at that point because of scarring and you have few choices left. I would highly recommend reading Dr. Walsh's book,"Guild to Surviving Prostate Cancer". One thing you will learn is that Drs. don't even know why we have a prostate. The other is that, that 3+4=7 may very well end up a 4+3=7 which is far worse. They won't know until the final path report after it is removed. I had non nerve sparing surgery and after meeting with the Dr. this past week he said it was a good thing because with the extent of the spreading he is afraid he would have missed some cancer right up against the nerves. And it isn't the end of the world, orgasms are like they were when I was young. Haven't been that way in years. At 10 weeks I am totally dry and back doing everything I did before.

Posts.Content: Hello Foosha, I agree with Chuck. I would steer clear of any Dr. that says surgery is bad. Removing the prostate is considered the Gold Standard of procedure's. And as to the "Nasty Side Affects' of surgery. I think most of us who have had it, will tell you that they are nothing that you can't deal with. Being alive and cancer free is far more important. Especially at the young age of 46, he has a lot of years ahead of him. Why take any chances with unproven procedures. Good luck, Lance

Posts.Title: First post-op PSA results

Posts.Content: wjw, LOL, Bladder control makes more sense. I didn't walk all that much during recovery. I find it harder to walk than ride. I walked a mile every day or so. I have an artificial right knee and Scoliosis, so riding my recumbent makes my back feel great. My bladder control never got that bad except for the first 2 days after the catheter was taken out. I can go through most days on 1 pad and nothing at night. I do get up about 3 times a night to empty my bladder, always afraid I'll leak if I don't. Hang in there it should get better. I was told to do 10 kegel's a day 10 times a day. That seemed to help, but then I kept reading where too many was bad, I backed off and started going down hill again. I am now doing 10 about 4 times a day.

Posts.Title: 6 Weeks Post Op

Posts.Content: I am now 8 weeks out Flkjr and pretty much the same story. At 3 weeks post op I was dry for a while. It just takes time from what I am reading. But you described me to a tee. wjw, I was told to not do anything beyond walking for six weeks by the hospital. My Dr. said I could ride my bike since it was a recumbent, but he said not to over do it. He suggested maybe 5 miles. I was doing 12 miles at 3- 4 weeks and not having any problems. Last weekend I rode 35 on Fri. and 29 on Sat. When we got home I felt a little sore through my belly area and thought I might have over done it so I wanted to loosen up the muscles and went for a short 7 mile ride. Then I got real sore. I started noticing that I was getting a burning sensation a little when I pee'd and contacted the Dr. She put me on Cipro for 7 days, (will finish Sun.) The pain went away after a couple days, but it was painful enough that I could barely walk. Bottom line, we went for a 28 mile ride today and I feel great. Planning on doing another 30 Sun. I have never gotten sore, no matter how much I have ridden, so I think it was the Urinary Infection that was causing it. Do you ride a recumbent? If so the Dr. might let you ride. However, if you ride an up right bike, I doubt that he is going to want any pressure on your crotch area. I know if I sit on anything that puts pressure up the crack it is still uncomfortable. I ride a trike so I am pretty much lying down, no pressure on the surgical area at all. About the bowel problems, I have never heard of anyone having that! Not having a BM for a couple days after surgery is normal but to not have control is another thing, Are you talking Diarrhea? I would take some Imodium if that is the case. Glad to hear you are felling so good. I felt great once the catheter was out. Lance

Posts.Title: 6 Weeks Post Op

Posts.Content: My uncle was a Gleason 9 and had EBR in 2007. In 2012 it came back. His Urologist is at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor and was told by him that there were only a few surgeons that would attempt it, and that most no longer did it, because, in his words, the results would be "Daunting and Morbid". They decided to go with Cryo Therapy where they freeze it. I understand that it is still fairly new but shows promise. You might ask about it. So far he is very pleased. PSA came back down and is now at .8. Good luck, Lance

Posts.Title: 6 Weeks Post Op

Posts.Content: Welcome Bob, Sorry you have to join us, but from what you have posted which is a little confusing, it doesn't sound too serious. Like Chuck said more info. will help. The numbers you gave don't make a whole lot of sense. You may just come out and ask your MD what your Gleason score is. Each score should reflect the total of 2 numbers, such as 3+3=6, 3+4=7 or worse yet, 4+3=7. The first number being the primary number or the one they found the most of in the core sample. Lance

Posts.Title: New Member Here!

Posts.Content: Israel, first welcome aboard our little club. Second don't worry, As long as you are staying on top of it, even if a biopsy comes back positive you will have most likely caught it early and you will have plenty of options. And even though you will hear all the horror stories about the side affects, I'm here to tell you most are highly blown out of proportion. I had mine removed 4 months ago and couldn't be happier with the results as you will hear most of the guy's who had RRP contest to. Lance

Posts.Title: 6 Weeks Post Op

Posts.Content: wjw, LOL, Bladder control makes more sense. I didn't walk all that much during recovery. I find it harder to walk than ride. I walked a mile every day or so. I have an artificial right knee and Scoliosis, so riding my recumbent makes my back feel great. My bladder control never got that bad except for the first 2 days after the catheter was taken out. I can go through most days on 1 pad and nothing at night. I do get up about 3 times a night to empty my bladder, always afraid I'll leak if I don't. Hang in there it should get better. I was told to do 10 kegel's a day 10 times a day. That seemed to help, but then I kept reading where too many was bad, I backed off and started going down hill again. I am now doing 10 about 4 times a day.

Posts.Title: Another nodule with low PSA

Posts.Content: I have asked within some other posts but never got a response, so I decided to start a thread. I had my nerves removed when I had RRP 7 weeks ago. The Dr. said in another month or so I could get a Penile Implant if I wanted. I have read up on them and seen some pretty good reviews and it seems most are pleased with the results. Especially the hydraulic types. Although I am having very good orgasm's, it would be nice to be able to try out my little fellow again. Is there anyone out there who can give me some 1st hand knowledge about them? I haven't seen them mentioned even from some who say they have had long term ED. Any feedback would be appreciated. Posts.Title: Penile Implants after non nerve sparing RRP?

Posts.Content: Sam, Welcome to our club. A Gleason score of 7 is moderately aggressive, so I wouldn't play it down too much. I was afraid to mention mine except to a few close friends until a couple days before I had my surgery. I would engage the advice of your Dr. relatives, that's more than most of us had. But the decision is ultimately yours as to where you go from here. Good luck and keep us informed. Lance

Posts.Title: Simple Biopsy Report

Posts.Content: DTrom, sorry to have to welcome you to our club. Sorrry to hear of your PSA rising. I have gad 2 so far and thankfully they have both been <.01. I too was a Gleason 4+3=7 and had mine removed last spring. I have been thinking of getting a Penile implant next spring, and have been unable to get any feedback on this forum. Could you please tell me if you are pleased with your choice. At 66 going on 67 in Mar. I want to have one, but question whether it is worth going through another surgery at this point in my life. I have great orgasms without penetration but long for the days when I could dip my wick in my wife. LOL I have read very good reviews about the procedure, but would like to hear it directly from someone who has had it done. Any feedback would be greatly appreciated. Lance

Posts.Title: Greetings from (near) Detroit

Posts.Content: DTrom, Thanks for the reply. I was considering the hydraulic type with everything inside the body, considered the best from what I have read. I have read that the circumference is larger & it is the most natural. But you mention of the head not being firm makes sense, as the tubes don't reach the head. I hadn't thought of that. Something to consider. At 67 which I'll be by then, I am inclined to just live with what I have. Let's face it, at this age sex is not my primary goal in life as it was when I was younger. My wife say's she is happy with the way things are. Lance

Posts.Title: First Few Days Home After Surgery - Do I need Someone Their Fulltime?

Posts.Content: Azsunshine, if you and you husband want to take T, more power to you. Sex is great, but it ain't worth loosing your life over in my opinion. Otherwise, I wouldn't have gone through with the surgery, knowing they were not going to be able to spare the nerves. I do plan on living possibly to 90, but I am healthy and stay physically active. I'm 66, I have ridden my bike 3800 miles over the last 18 mos. and I kayak once a week for about 10 miles, and I ride horses every weekend. I have lost 90 lbs. over the last couple years staying on a low carb diet. I am now down to a healthy 152. I am not trying to sound sarcastic, I am just saying living to a ripe old age does not have to be bad! Good luck!

Posts.Title: Prostate cancer and sex drive

Posts.Content: Walt_Green, this may be true. However, like in my case I won't know for perhaps years if it has spread because it takes that long to know. That's why I have to have my PSA checked every 3 mos. for a couple years, then every 6mos. and so on. I have a 50/50 chance of it coming back within 10 yrs. I have read on this forum of a number of guy's that when it came back it was in their bones or elsewhere. Taking T would be feeding it even though you didn't think it had metastasized. Don't think I would want to take the chance. Seems to me it might have been Newporter, I may be mistaken though.

Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About ED

Posts.Content: ddayglo, Just Kegals, (pretend you are trying to hold back a fart). I was getting conflicting messages. At my 1 week post op appointment I was told to do 10, 10 times a day and try to get to where I could hold them for 10 seconds. (By the way I was told to start them 2 weeks prior to the surgery). You can't do them with the cath. in. So I was doing them religiously. I didn't feel I was making too much progress at first. Then I remembered that Dr. Walsh said not to do too many or you will tire out the muscle and end up wetter. So the last few days I backed off from doing so many and bingo I got better within 2 or 3 days. The other thing was that Dr. Walsh said to always do them standing up and to stop & start your urine flow. Hell, all I was getting was dribbles there was no flow. I found them easier to do sitting on the toilet, as I have heard others say worked for them. So it must have been a combination of doing a lot to strengthen the muscle then backing off and letting it do it's thing. Lance

Posts.Title: Dry, less the 3 weeks post surgery .

Posts.Content: Hay, sorry you are so down. I am having the surgery on the 25th of June, can't wait! Maybe I will have side effects, have already been told they are not going to try to save the nerves. But the way I look at it, better alive than dead. If your girl friend couldn't stand by you, then she wasn't for you anyway. Hang in there, there are women out there that will appreciate you for your companionship & love. I am married to one, it has never crossed my mind that she would leave me just because I can't get it up or that I piss the bed. Lance
Posts.Title: Prostate operation 9 weeks ago

Posts.Content: I have had 2 post op PSA tests and haven't altered my daily behavior at all. Lance

Posts.Title: The count down

Posts.Content: A little Neosporin on the tip with pain reliever works great. Never had any discomfort. They had me remove the catheter myself after 7 days bout 4-6 hrs. before my appointment so that they could see I was doing okay. Otherwise if they take it out in the office, you get sent home and they don't know how you are doing. They told me stairs were fine, but no lifting anything over 20# for 6 weeks. I cheated a little on the lifting, but at 5 weeks I am feeling great.

Posts.Title: Hello from a newbie and a couple of questions.

Posts.Content: I find it encouraging that you hit a plateau and stayed there for a while. I was doing great down to a single Depends Shield and the last few days I have not been able to hold anything back, just leaks every time I bend over or stand up. I'm at 8 weeks as of yesterday. So maybe there is hope for me yet. Glad to hear you are doing so good njs. I get my first PSA next week. Crossing my fingers.

Posts.Title: 10 weeks post-op

Posts.Content: A little Neosporin on the tip with pain reliever works great. Never had any discomfort. They had me remove the catheter myself after 7 days bout 4-6 hrs. before my appointment so that they could see I was doing okay. Otherwise if they take it out in the office, you get sent home and they don't know how you are doing. They told me stairs were fine, but no lifting anything over 20# for 6 weeks. I cheated a little on the lifting, but at 5 weeks I am feeling great.
